Subject: Re: [junit] Re: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts
From: Vladimir Bossicard <vladimir@...>

> Mind if I ask why exactly do you want a empty test method there? 

I don't want anything!  It's not an empty method, it's a method that is currently empty but will be written later.

> What is the difference if you just add the method later?

I just pointed out that if you really want an empty method (with no assertion -> reported as successfull by JUnit) you must add some note to not forget to write the code.  If you don't I'm sure you'll forget at the end of the project that you still have somewhere (dude, where's my empty method?) code to write.

If you declare your method "_notImplemented" :
1) you can only define one unimplemented method per TestCase
2) you don't code anything meaningfull.  If you want to write a template, the method's name should at least mean something (such as "testThrowExceptionA"...).

I imagine a tool that parses your classes and generates a specific TestCase class with methods to test your public methods?  Let's say: you have a method that can throw exceptions A, B or C, your generated file will have 3 methods (testThrowA, testThrowB, testThrowC...) with (almost) empty bodies.  Does it make sense?

BTW anyone thinks that it is a good idea? (the tool is IDE independant of course).

-Vladimir
subject: Re: [junit] Re: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts
